quoteFirst: Jones wanted to come along with me? I was glad and grateful. I don't know that I could have stood being al
title: The Little Man Who Wasn't Quite
author: Stuart, William W.; Walker [Illustrator]

quoteLast: in the morning, I was seized with dreadful fatigue. My limbs stiffened under the strain of violent cramp. Conseil was obliged to keep me up, and our preservation devolved on him alone.
title: Twenty Thousand Leagues under the Sea
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteFirst: _October 26th._--The transport _Malay_ broke some of her machinery
quoteLast: last night. The whole fleet stopped and waited until she had made the defect good. We remained on the spot till 7 a.m. The _Malay_ repaired engines and the fleet proceeded. We wasted six hours over it. I count every hour.
title:
From Libau to Tsushima
A narrative of the voyage of Admiral Rojdestvensky's fleet to eastern seas, including a detailed account of the Dogger Bank incident
author: Politovskii, Evgenii Sigizmundovich, 1874-1905; Godfrey, Frederick Rowlandson, 1867- [Translator]

quoteFirst: Then work begins.  Water is procured from ice, tools mended, etcetera.  The crew dine
quoteLast: , the officers at 2:30.  The latter go for a walk or rehearse theatricals.  Going out, the air smells like green walnuts, says Doctor Moss.
title: Notable Voyagers, From Columbus to Nordenskiold
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880; Frith, Henry, 1840-

quoteFirst: But his precautions were useless, for, when he called at the hotel the next morning, he learned that Mr. Hardman had come in at midnight, had paid his bill, and departed on the
title: Frank Roscoe's Secret; Or, the Darewell Chums in the Woods
author: Chapman, Allen

quoteLast: the Fishers' Hall was dark and still, and the echo of a tender little laugh or song from some couple, who had taken the longest way round for the nearest way home, was all that remained of the mirth and melody of the evening. Angus and Christine sauntered slowly through the village.
title: Christine: A Fife Fisher Girl
author: Barr, Amelia E., 1831-1919; Mulford, Stockton, 1886-1960 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The silence was so profound I could scarcely believe the three men sat there with eye and ear strained to catch the least movement—the slightest sound. Minute after minute passed slowly—slowly.  I could not sleep.  A thousand terrible images chased each other through my brain.
title: Brigadier Frederick; and, The Dean's Watch
author: Erckmann-Chatrian; Burton, Richard, 1861-1940 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Soon after assuming charge of the office, General Black issued his famous order, number 110, whereby all employes were required to be at their desks at nine o’clock, A.M., and
quoteLast: , P.M., thirty minutes being allowed for lunch, from twelve thirty P.M., and to remain at their desks, until four o’clock, P.M., when the office closed. Chiefs of divisions were required to see that order strictly enforced, and to report all violators of it, to the Commissioner immediately, and he would require the violator to write him a letter, explaining the cause of tardiness.
title: The New Man: Twenty-nine years a slave, twenty-nine years a free man
author: Bruce, Henry Clay, 1836-1902

quoteFirst: I knew I should be too sleepy to put the extra things on, so I plumped them all on before I went to sleep. Tonight we are going to be supplied with extra blankets. It’s now a little after
quoteLast: and the heat is quite uncomfortable; it seems stupid to be talking of blankets.”
title: Sicily in Shadow and in Sun: The Earthquake and the American Relief Work
author: Elliott, Maud Howe, 1854-1948

quoteFirst: The German reserves, even as late as July 20th, numbered some thirty-five divisions opposite this part of the front alone, and, with the presence of such an enemy concentration, it was only natural that there should be continued warnings and alarms of impending attacks. On July 21st the wagon-lines of all batteries were ordered to "stand by" throughout the night, with teams fully harnessed up; on July 24th a message was received
quoteLast: that the enemy would attack at dawn.
title: The History of the 33rd Divisional Artillery, in the War, 1914-1918.
author: Macartney-Filgate, John Victor; Horne, Henry, 1861-1929 [Author of introduction, etc.]
